plants.name: Prunus serrulata
plants.description: A deciduous tree famous for its stunning and delicate pink flowers that signal the arrival of spring in many temperate regions. These blossoms create spectacular displays in parks and gardens.
plants.location: Temperate regions of Japan, Korea, China, and cultivated in many temperate zones worldwide
plants.funFact: The Japanese Cherry Blossom has inspired festivals (Hanami) celebrating transient beauty, as the flowers bloom briefly and fall quickly.

plants.name: Magnolia Ã— soulangeana
plants.description: A hybrid magnolia known for its large, tulip-shaped flowers that bloom early in spring, often before the leaves emerge. They are prized ornamentals for gardens and parks.
plants.location: Native to China and cultivated widely in temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere
plants.funFact: Magnolia flowers evolved before bees existed; early magnolias were pollinated by beetles, one of the oldest pollinators.

plants.name: Waratah (Telopea speciosissima)
plants.description: An iconic Australian native shrub bearing large, bright red flower heads that bloom in early spring. It is the floral emblem of New South Wales, Australia.
plants.bloomingSeason: September to November in Australia but blooms in the Southern Hemisphere spring, which corresponds to March in the Northern Hemisphere when cultivated under controlled conditions.
plants.location: Eastern Australia, especially New South Wales
plants.funFact: Waratah flowers are rich in nectar and attract birds and insects, playing a key role in local ecosystems.

plants.name: Crocus vernus
plants.description: A small perennial bulbous plant that produces cup-shaped flowers early in spring, often poking through snow. It is a classic harbinger of spring in temperate regions.
plants.location: Europe and Western Asia, also cultivated in gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Some crocus species produce saffron from their stigmas, one of the most expensive spices globally.
